fields.summary: Cannot Create a review from a ClearCase changeset which contains deletions

fields.description:
*1. Branch drop down:*
- allow user to know which ones are the deleted branches
*or*
- don't display the deleted branches at all

*2. In the changeset screen:* 
- make clear if it is from a deleted changeset.
- allow the admin to hide the change sets from users and make them available in the reviews only.

*3. In the JIRA issue Review and Source tabs:* 
- Source tab: Don't show deleted branches info *or* allow the admin to hide them *or* make clear in the UI that the branches were deleted.
- Review tab: continue showing the information

*Very Good to Have:* auto detection of a _rebase from a deleted branch to an existing branch_ and reroute all the pointers to the rebased entry. This would allow the information forom a deleted branch to go away completely and the information in FeCru to continue consistent.
fields.summary: Improve UI communication for information related to deleted branches
Admin: migrate admin screens to AUI

fields.description:
I'm trying FishEye using a Mercurial as repository. In this situation when I try to view a Source file, I can't visualize all the width of my source file. It is very uncomfortable for me. the attachment illustrate my problem. I can't resize the column in witch there are the drop down for the version of a file. I think that the problem is rised because mercurial has a log number for a version number.

The first photo represent my screen, in the second I have highlighted want I should want.

Thanks
fields.summary: Problem in visualization of Source, using Mercurial

fields.description: I noticed today that FECRU is bundled both google-collections 1.0 and guava r06 in the lib directory.  To plugins, FECRU is exporting com.google.{common,base} as version 1.0, but com.google.{io, net, primitives, util.concurrent} without versions.  Is there a reason to bundle both the older google-collections and guava libs?  Can we please please please specify versions for everything that is exported?  In the case of guava, since the version is r06, the exported package version should be 6.0.0.
fields.summary: Google collections and Guava both bundled, package exported without version
Hg version check fails if OS is using a non-English locale

fields.description:
to reproduce, select Custom symbolic rules
add a tag rule
delete the new tag rule
delete the original tag rule
now, you can no longer add a new tag rule

add a new trunk rule
delete the new trunk rule
now, you can no longer add a new trunk rule

you end up with something like this
!https://img.skitch.com/20110815-c5txyu43i4smdccbtcd1m45fey.png!
fields.summary: adding and deleting svn symbolic rules via the admin leaves the UI in an inconsistent state

fields.description:
We have a Windows Server running FishEye 2.4.4 and are planning an upgrade to 2.6.3 but we have identifed this issue.

Naturally I am aiming for a test server install to create the repository index which can then be copied across to the server.
When querying the Mecurial Repository from the Test Server - Error referencing a duplicate clone is displayed when trying to reindex. I have tried using the "Reindex existing clone" option but It still attempts to clone the repository.

The reason for upgrading was initially to overcome the slow speeds associated with indexing the Mecurial Repo from 2.4.4 and to use a mssql database instead of hsql. (Currently the existing Mecurial Repository is indexing - hasnt finished in 2 months - this could be because of slow network links but would this affect Fisheye's ability to determine whether there is an existing clone).

Pls advise if this error has ever been seen before and how we could resolve it.
fields.summary: Fisheye 2.6.3 on Windows Platform

fields.description:

(See attached Screenshot)
fields.summary: Fishey Crowd integration doesn't work when the group name has a space

fields.description:
Today it's possible to start FECRU through the command line specifying the flags {{"--Xdisable-head-detection"}} and {{"--Xdisable-tags"}}:

http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/FISHEYE/Command-Line+Options

It would be awesome if it was possible to make FishEye / Crucible toggle these options through the administration panel as well and save this in a configuration file, as customers that need to use these flags must always remember to start FishEye / Crucible from the command line specifying these flags when the application needs to be restarted, otherwise they may have performance problems.
fields.summary: Toggle flags from the UI

fields.description:
I have added JIRA as an Application Link to FishEye, and it's using Trusted Applications.
The integration works perfectly in both sides.
In FishEye, I have configured JIRA this way:
* Application URL: http://ecrnt-11:8080 
This is the URL used to connect to the remote application from this server.
* Display URL: http://localhost:8080
The display URL is used when rendering links to the application in the user's browser.

However, when I hover a JIRA issue key in the activity stream, *sometimes* the link to the JIRA issue is displayed incorrectly.

See {{img1.jpg}} attached displaying {{http://localhost:8080/browse/JRA-1}} (correct).
See {{img2.jpg}} attached displaying {{http://ecrnt-11:8080/browse/JRA-1}} (incorrect).

Please also note that I hovered the same JIRA Issue Key.

However, clicking on the JIRA Issue Key with *wrong* link (http://ecrnt-11:8080/browse/JRA-1) also redirects me to the *correct* issue page in JIRA, and that hovering works for in both cases.
fields.summary: JIRA links do not respect the Display URL field

fields.description:
The following in the svn repo spec:

{code}
<tag regex="" name="" logical=""/>
{code}

will mean that trunk will never be matched!

See screenshot attached.
Adding anything to the <tag regex=""/> e.g. regex="xxx" will allow trunk to match correctly.

This is counter-intuitive if you wished to exclude all your tags from FE indexing, say.
fields.summary: Empty "tag" definition for Subversion Repos, overrides the trunk RegExp

fields.description:
This issue has been created based on the feedback on FE-137.

The input into includes, excludes and definitions of branch/tag/trunk take very different input.

For example, includes cannot be regexps, while branch/tag/trunk can be. Excludes can use Ant Globs.

The Admin UI does not make this very clear at all.

From the discussion on FE-137 it looks like we cannot make these fields take the same kind of input due to performance reasons. For example, it is not possible to make includes take regexps.

We should ensure, however, that the UI in FishEye makes it very clear what field can take what input.
fields.summary: Update the UI to clearly explain what input format the repository includes, excludes and definitions of branch/tag/trunk can take

fields.description:
According to [this post|https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/FE-1949?focusedCommentId=185821&page=com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.issuetabpanels:comment-tabpanel#comment-185821] the value should not contain the Repo URL or Path:
{quote}
The path you enter for path testing is the path within the FishEye repository definition. It should not include the Repository URL (i.e. the http:// component and hostname) or the repository path.

If you were to test with this path

ASToolkitJava/TRUNK/src/test

it would work without issues.
{quote}

However the natural string that the admin will provide is the Full URL.

One of the following solutions would be great:

1. Add a better UI description/label to the text box

OR

2. Allow the admin to add the full URL and then parse it based on the already provided "SVN URL" and "Path" fields provided at the "SVN Connection Details" section.
fields.summary: Improve UI communication for the SVN Symbolic Rules "Test Path" field

fields.description:
Somehow, the following is the output of:

hg branches -C
00 00 00 00 00 00 00 20 20 20 20 20 20 20 20 20 20 20 20 20 20 20 20 20 20 20 20 20 35 33 39 30 3A
(in HEX).

The NULs at the beginning cause fisheye to think that a branch-name exists, however later this gets .trim()med and is therefore empty.

FishEye should skip any branch it encounters without a name.
fields.summary: FishEye chokes on a changeset that has an 'empty' branch name

fields.description:
This appears related to CRUC-5162.  

The rescan feature in FishEye/Crucible is not updating the comments in Fisheye and not updating the link in JIRA. 

After changing the JIRA Issue key in a submitted Perforce changelist (e.g. TS-100 ... changed to TS-101...), and executing a rescan on that changelist the following events are expected:

1) The comment in Fisheye reflects the updated description
2) The 'links' in JIRA are updated to reflect the change (i.e. issue TS-100 no longer references the changelist, and TS-101 references the changelist)
3) The changelist comment in JIRA is updated to reflect the change

Items 1 & 2 are not occurring without a full re-index of the repository.  

Steps to Reproduce
 (Assumes JIRA/FishEye integration is configured and functioning properly)
 1) Create JIRA issues TS-100 & TS-101
 2) Submit Perforce changelist with description 'TS-100 - Rename/move files(s)'
 3) Confirm FishEye and issue TS-100 reflect submitted changelist
 4) Edit description in Perforce changelist created in step 2 to 'TS-101 - Rename/move files(s)'
 5) Perform Rescan in FishEye UI specifying Perforce changelist created in Step 2 in From and To revision.

Expected Results:
 1) The 'Source' tab in JIRA for issue TS-100 is empty (i.e. no longer references the changelist)
 2) The 'Source' tab in JIRA for issue TS-101 shows the perforce changelist information
 3) The FishEye dashboard for the user that submitted the changelist is updated to reflect the updated changelist description.  

Actual Results:
 1) The 'Source' tab in JIRA for issue TS-100 still shows the perforce changelist information (although the description reflects the change)
 2) The 'Source' tab in JIRA for issue TS-101 is empty
 3) The FishEye dashboard for the user that submitted the changelist shows the old changelist description


Thanks,
Craig
fields.summary: Rescan commit comments in Perforce repositories not working

fields.description:
Provide a repository administration option to set character encoding for file content for Git repositories (by default it should use UTF-8). Currently, Fisheye supports changing the file encoding for Perforce, SVN, and CVS.

*Similar issues:*

FE-6961 for Mercurial 


*Original request:*

Please support arbitrary file encoding by using 'encoding' property in .gitattributes.
fields.summary: Add option to set default charset encoding for file content for Git repositories

fields.description:
Fisheye does not appear to display the displaynames correctly for users where their firstname and lastname fields are null in JIRA database (cwd_user table). These fields can be null for very old versions of JIRA such as 3.7.1 or when upgrading from an old version similar to 3.7.x.
If the firstname and lastname are null in JIRA database, Fisheye uses the username rather than the displayname to fetch the display name for the affected user.

Replicated locally with following steps:

1) Install JIRA 3.7.1
2) Created 2 new users "admin371" and "user1"
3) Checked db, they just had fullname, no first or last name columns in JIRA DB. JIRA DB schema for this version is [here|http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRA03x/Database+Schema#DatabaseSchema-Userdetails].
4) Upgraded JIRA to 4.3.4
5) Checked the db tables again. This time, the fullname was split into first and last name. Fullname was stored under displayname field in CWD_user table. The Firstname and lastname fields were null.
6) Added a new user in 4.3.4. This user had their fullname split into first and last name in the db.
7) Delegated user management to JIRA in Fisheye 2.6.1
8) The result was that the original JIRA users coming from 3.7.1 had their displaynames same as usernames, since their first and last names were empty. New JIRA users had their display names correctly shown in Fisheye.

Enabled HTTP wire logging in Fisheye for original JIRA 3.7.1 user "user1" and authenticated them for the first time in Fisheye. The output is below:

fields.description:
This is due to the way the class handle the file name, it should keep the defined extension and add the proper date to the actual _name_ of the file and not to the name+extension.
Currently instead of viewing the build log in browser, we have to download it, open it and select an application to open it.

This change *cannot* be made on the by simply changing the _log4j.xml_ file, as this behaviuor is coded on the actual DailyRollingFileAppender class.

Today it creates files like this:
{noformat}
fisheye-debug.log.2011-08-02
fisheye-mail.log.2011-07-26
fisheye-dbdebug.log.2011-07-26
fisheye-debug.log.2011-07-29
fisheye-error.log.2011-07-22
{noformat}

Where the expected would be:
{noformat}
fisheye-debug.2011-08-02.log
fisheye-mail.2011-07-26.log
fisheye-dbdebug.2011-07-26.log
fisheye-debug.2011-07-29.log
fisheye-error.2011-07-22.log
{noformat}
fields.summary: Change com.cenqua.fisheye.logging.DailyRollingFileAppender to keep the extension .log

fields.description:
If a changeset has a earlier date than the changeset a file was last modified in, when you look at the diff in the file diff view, FishEye orders the two revisions based on date and displays the opposite diff to what is expected.
Note the changeset page shows the correct diff, but if you click on the delta icon for a file, it shows the opposite
fields.summary: File Diff is showing the opposite to what actually happened

fields.description:
If a commit message contains an issue key that is wrapped in square brackets, e.g: \[JRA-9\], the Commit Messages quick search results do not link the issue correctly.
Instead of going to the http://jirahost/jira/browse/JRA-9, the link is simply relative to the FishEye instance. ie: http://fisheyehost/JRA-9 . 

This is most likely caused by a combination square brackets clashing with the wiki-rendering and also the hit-highlighting logic applied to search results.

We need to investigate however this is not occurring on the changeset page in FishEye, just the search results.
fields.summary: Issue keys, wrapped in square brackets [JRA-9] are not linked correctly in quick search results
Setting a user's authentication type to other than 'built in' when 'built in' is in use causes NPE when editing that user's details

fields.description:
Imagine the scenario where you have 20+ repositories. If a user has committed in the past with a different email, you'd have to create mappings 20+ times, once per repo.  

Can we specify a global user mapping, and only have it overwritten if there's a specific repo mapping?
fields.summary: Support global user mappings

fields.description:
We need to display much clearer and user friendly eror messages for the following cases:
* the remote server hosting JIRA is unreachable
* JIRA is down, or not running on port <PORT>.
* JIRA is up, though the Remote API is disabled
* JIRA doesn't have the required plugins installed to function with FishEye
* JIRA's version is outdated and not compatible with the current version of FishEye
* FishEye doesn't have the appropriate credentials to contact the remote server
fields.summary: Improve error messages when linking to an issue fails.

fields.description:
Hovering over the 'Time Spent' field should prompt the user to Authenticate with JIRA, just as clicking the 'link to JIRA' link does on the same page.

This behaviour is extremely counter-intuitive and confusing to users.

To reproduce:
# setup App Links using OAuth to JIRA
# configure App Links between Crucible and JIRA
# create a JIRA issue
# commit code against that issue
# create a review from that changeset
# hover over the 'Time Spent' field at the top of the review - nothing happens
# click the 'link to JIRA' link on the page - get prompted to auth with JIRA. *NB* the review is still linked via the commit message.
# hover over the 'Time Spent' field - pop-over appears.
fields.summary: Hovering over 'Time spent' field in Crucible doesn't show 'Log time to JIRA pop-over' - unless user has done the OAuth dance

fields.description:
Necessary information:
1. What is it for?
2. How does it work?
3. Make clear that if usernames or emails match between the repo and the Fisheye user, the mapping will be automatic.

See attached screen shot.
fields.summary: Document User Mappings

fields.description:
Big and multiple repositories can be a problem for Admins that want to map the Repo Users with the Built-In/LDAP/JIRA/Crowd users.

The mapping would be easier if every user could do its own mapping by claiming its name in each repo. The claim would be approved if he is able to login to the Repo with that user name.
fields.summary: Allow every user to claim his Repo User Mapping with the local User Name

fields.description:
This can cause a TooManyOpenFiles exception for large CVS repositories during an upgrade from FishEye 2.5 --> 2.6.

This will not affect a running CVS repository.

*WORKAROUND* delete the repository's cache at FISHEYE_INST/var/cache/<reponame> to trigger a full clean slurp of the repo.

Also note however - this will been fixed in FishEye 2.6.3.
fields.summary: Upgrading of CVS repositories leaves file handles open...

fields.description:
Feedback from customer:
{quote}
Using Jira 4.3.4 and Fisheye+Crucible 2.5.4, the docs didn't tell me that the method of configuring links between Fisheye repos and Jira projects was now done from each project's administration page, rather than from the Fisheye Configuration admin console page as it was in earlier versions.

The only correct info that I could see was presented in the UI just after setting the application link to my Fisheye+Crucible instance. Once this message is dismissed, I didn't see any other way back to it.

I'd suggest having some in-line documentation in the UI, and updating this doc to reflect the new project-to-repo mapping procedure:

https://studio.plugins.atlassian.com/wiki/display/FISH/FishEye+for+JIRA+User%27s+Guide
{quote}

Docs are very light on configuration, the only issue touched upon is the different types of authentication.
fields.summary: Improve JIRA FishEye plugin configuration documentation

fields.description:
Description: Current HTTP headers do not contain the X-FRAME-Option, which helps prevents against Clickjacking attacks. A Clickjacking attack is similar to CSRF in which attacker can hijack a "click" on a web application from another "invisible" frame in the browser. Essentially, an attacker can force a user to click on a button that is invisible to him/her.

Exploit Scenario: An attacker crafts a malicious page such that when their victim clicks, they are actually clicking on the link or button in the vulnerable application hosted in an iframe. Thus, an attacker tricks the user into performing an action of the attacker's choosing by directing mouse input to the target application.

Short Term Solution: There are 2 options in the HTTP response header for projection, include:

DENY: If the header contains the DENY option, then the response will not be loaded within a frame.
SAMEORIGIN: If the header contains the SAMEORIGIN option, the response will be loaded within a frame only if the parent page is from the same origin.

Examples below:

Apache:
Add this to your httpd.conf:
Header always append x-frame-options SAMEORIGIN

Note that this is not a panacea for clickjacking.

SAMEORIGIN should be safe to use. See also [JST-5291|https://studio.atlassian.com/browse/JST-5291?focusedCommentId=47107&page=com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.issuetabpanels:comment-tabpanel#comment-47107]
fields.summary: Enable X-FRAME-Option in HTTP response headers in order to improve clickjacking protection

fields.description:
If I include a full Git hash in a '{cs:id=' link it shows the full hash rather than an abbreviation.

If I abbreviate it myself too much, it will let me use an ambiguous hash '{cs:id=a|rep=repo.git}' and will pick an arbitrary commit rather than showing an error.
fields.summary: Git changeset links should abbreviate hashes

fields.description:
This is because when the frxs get sorted, we are not checking for null branches.

In the case of a tag in svn, there may not be a branch associated with a FRX.

This is the case when there is no activity (no revisions) for a FRX, for example.
fields.summary: When a file on a tag is added to a review, the review can not be reviewed due to a NPE

fields.description: Fisheye/Crucible should use database schemas when using SQL server as the back end. This would allow us to host the full suite of Atlassian products in a single database.
fields.summary: MS SQL Server back-end to use schemas

fields.description:
When serving a file, FE can OOM, before any content is rendered. This only occurs on large files. Adding a system setting (preferably controllable by a remote API and through an admin page) to set the max size of files to be served would be really helpful.

Files that are not rendered could be replaced with a message saying it's too large.
fields.summary: Please create a setting to restrict the size of files served

fields.description:
The connection to the repository worked perfectly, then I made two commits, and Fisheye came back with the following error message:

Repository index failed due to error com.cenqua.fisheye.rep.RepositoryClientException: com.atlassian.fisheye.dvcs.handler.DvcsProcessException: Error while communicating with VCS: ** unknown exception encountered, please report by visiting ** http://mercurial.selenic.com/wiki/BugTracker ** Python 2.6.6 (r266:84297, Aug 24 2010, 18:13:38) [MSC v.1500 64 bit (AMD64)] ** Mercurial Distributed SCM (version 1.9+10-e9264b45237d) ** Extensions loaded: felog Traceback (most recent call last): File "hg", line 42, in <module> File "mercurial\dispatch.pyo", line 27, in run File "mercurial\dispatch.pyo", line 64, in dispatch File "mercurial\dispatch.pyo", line 87, in _runcatch File "mercurial\dispatch.pyo", line 675, in _dispatch File "mercurial\dispatch.pyo", line 454, in runcommand File "mercurial\dispatch.pyo", line 729, in _runcommand File "mercurial\dispatch.pyo", line 683, in checkargs File "mercurial\dispatch.pyo", line 672, in <lambda> File "mercurial\util.pyo", line 385, in check File "C:\Servers\CrucibleFisheye\python\hg\hgfelog\hgfelog.py", line 77, in felog for r in cmdutil.revrange(repo, [n]): AttributeError: 'module' object has no attribute 'revrange' com.atlassian.fisheye.dvcs.handler.DvcsProcessException: Error while communicating with VCS: ** unknown exception encountered, please report by visiting ** http://mercurial.selenic.com/wiki/BugTracker ** Python 2.6.6 (r266:84297, Aug 24 2010, 18:13:38) [MSC v.1500 64 bit (AMD64)] ** Mercurial Distributed SCM (version 1.9+10-e9264b45237d) ** Extensions loaded: felog Traceback (most recent call last): File "hg", line 42, in <module> File "mercurial\dispatch.pyo", line 27, in run File "mercurial\dispatch.pyo", line 64, in dispatch File "mercurial\dispatch.pyo", line 87, in _runcatch File "mercurial\dispatch.pyo", line 675, in _dispatch File "mercurial\dispatch.pyo", line 454, in runcommand File "mercurial\dispatch.pyo", line 729, in _runcommand File "mercurial\dispatch.pyo", line 683, in checkargs File "mercurial\dispatch.pyo", line 672, in <lambda> File "mercurial\util.pyo", line 385, in check File "C:\Servers\CrucibleFisheye\python\hg\hgfelog\hgfelog.py", line 77, in felog for r in cmdutil.revrange(repo, [n]): AttributeError: 'module' object has no attribute 'revrange' com.atlassian.utils.process.ProcessException: While executing: "hg --config extensions.felog=C:\Servers\CrucibleFisheye\python\hg\hgfelog\hgfelog.py --config ui.verbose=false felog d238991115984ed228265debffe29ba99b4543c5 -p -m " com.atlassian.utils.process.ProcessException: java.lang.NullPointerException java.lang.NullPointerException: null

I have checked, it's the same message with all my Bitbucket.org repos. I am not 100% sure that whether it's a Fisheye or a Bitbucket.org problem, but it Fisheye seems to be the more likely source.

As a result of this error, Fisheye doesn't show anything from Bitbucket.org, every repository showing up with the State Error, and empty history (Commits 0).
fields.summary: Repository index failed - Fisheye and Bitbucket repository

fields.description:
Occurs when you have 2 users accessing the same SVN server containing 2 different repositories each with different authentication details, where the user for 1 cannot access the path of the other and vice-versa.

SVN Kit appears to ignore the authentication options set in the FishEye Admin UI and use the options from the different repository on the same svn server - if these don't have access to that path, we get an authentication error.
fields.summary: SVN: Authentication to second SVN repository on the same server fails

fields.description: Currently we have migration from HSQL to other external database. It would be good if FishEye/crucible UI is able to have a feature to migrate from one external database to another external database(eg: MySQL migrate to Oracle).
fields.summary: Enable user to migrate External database to another external database via FIshEye/Crucible UI

Could this be down to git only looking for copies of files that have changed in the same commit? {{--find-copies-harder}} would be great in reviews that copy an existing file without changing the original.

fields.description:
This error is ocuring in all our CVS repositories:

{code}2011-07-03 04:41:34,584 ERROR [IncrementalPinger1 ] fisheye.app com.cenqua.fisheye.cvsrep.cache.CvsHistoryChangeDetector-doRunOnce - problem with initial scan
com.cenqua.fisheye.rep.DbException: Error during upgrade task upgrade-changeset-ancestry-3 on <cvs_repository_name>
        at com.cenqua.fisheye.rep.impl.BaseUpgradeTask.upgrade(BaseUpgradeTask.java:67)
        at com.cenqua.fisheye.cvsrep.cache.CachedCvsRepositoryUpdater.upgrade(CachedCvsRepositoryUpdater.java:293)
        at com.cenqua.fisheye.cvsrep.cache.CvsHistoryChangeDetector.doRunOnce(CvsHistoryChangeDetector.java:117)
        at com.cenqua.fisheye.cvsrep.cache.CvsHistoryChangeDetector.ping(CvsHistoryChangeDetector.java:54)
        at com.cenqua.fisheye.cvsrep.cache.CachedCvsRepositoryUpdater.pingSlurp(CachedCvsRepositoryUpdater.java:279)
        at com.cenqua.fisheye.cvsrep.CvsRepositoryEngine.doSlurp(CvsRepositoryEngine.java:68)
        at com.cenqua.fisheye.rep.RepositoryEngine.slurp(RepositoryEngine.java:390)
        at com.cenqua.fisheye.rep.ping.OneOffPingRequest.doRequest(OneOffPingRequest.java:25)
        at com.cenqua.fisheye.rep.ping.PingRequest.process(PingRequest.java:66)
        at com.cenqua.fisheye.rep.RepositoryHandle.processPingRequests(RepositoryHandle.java:132)
        at com.cenqua.fisheye.rep.RepositoryHandle.queuePingRequest(RepositoryHandle.java:122)
        at com.cenqua.fisheye.rep.ping.PingRequest.run(PingRequest.java:33)
        at java.util.concurrent.ThreadPoolExecutor$Worker.runTask(ThreadPoolExecutor.java:886)
        at java.util.concurrent.ThreadPoolExecutor$Worker.run(ThreadPoolExecutor.java:908)
        at java.lang.Thread.run(Thread.java:619)
{code}

Ater that it continuously throws the following warning:

{code}2011-07-06 15:49:10,112 WARN  [IncrementalPinger1 ] fisheye.app com.cenqua.fisheye.rep.impl.TopologicalOrderChangesetIterator-addCsAndParentsToFront - TopologicalOrderChangesetIterator.addCsAndParentsToFront: Cyclic Ancestry Detected: [<branch>:<commiter>:20010906035716(<branch>:<commiter>:20010905030326,), ][<branch>:<commiter>:20010821002214(<branch>:<commiter>:20010906035716,), <branch>:<commiter>:20010905030326(<branch>:<commiter>:20010821002214,), <branch>:<commiter>:20010908015841(<branch>:<commiter>:20010906035716,), <branch>:<commiter>:20010717175148(<branch>:<commiter>:20010908015841,), ]
{code}

It then causes the application to hang. And in the admin's repository view, the currently being scanned repositories have the following:

{code}
Info

Upgrading Ancestry for ChangeSet: <branch>:<commiter>:20010906035716 (x of n)
{code}

Although we can trigger individual repository indexing manually, this bug prevents automatic indexing to occur and takes up all of the CPU core (and then some) it's running on.

This seems to be a show stopper for our very active instance of Fisheye/Crucible and prevents any reviews/work to be done in coordination with this product.

If there is anything I can provide to help fix this bug, please say so.

See screen shot
fields.summary: Admin Repositories page show a maximum of 10 repositories.

fields.description:
We are using a topic-branch model in which we do lots of rebases.  When the topic branches are completed, some of them end up in a not fully merged state, but are deleted from the server anyway.

When the git client tries to delete the branch it is getting an error due to the use of the "git branch -d" command to remove the branch.

Using "git branch -D" would force the removal of the local branch, which should be done anyway because the Fisheye is just a reflection of the repository as it is.
fields.summary: Git plugin fails to delete 'not fully merged' branch

fields.description:
On a local test Git repo, the following files with cyrillic characters and diacritics creates indexing warnings:
{noformat}
14:47:58:git-test-repo $ ls
README				filewithcyЄҎillicл-new.txt
README.txt			filewithcyЄҎillicл.txt
filewithgreεkleηtϴer.txt	filéwithaccènt.txt
{noformat}

From {{git whatchanged}}, Git added those files using antislashes in their names:
{noformat}
commit 2cf4f6066b4b7a63d24a9ecb4e85a65a2667bc54
Author: pepoirot
Date:   Mon Jun 27 12:13:42 2011 +1000
    Add file with cyrillics and greeks characters

:000000 100644 0000000... 9daeafb... A  "filewithcy\320\204\322\216illic\320\273.txt"
:000000 100644 0000000... 9daeafb... A  "filewithgre\316\265kle\316\267t\317\264er.txt"
{noformat}

And this creates warnings when indexing later commits:
{noformat}
     [java] 2011-06-27 14:45:54,485 WARN  - Inconsistent state while finding the revision for file at path "filewi\314\202tha\314\200cce\314\200nt.txt" at changeset f1386cd4898696663f83bf62c8f5bc4dc1b463d1. No revision returned by git.Content hash was: 9daeafb9864cf43055ae93beb0afd6c7d144bfa4
     [java] 2011-06-27 14:45:54,541 WARN  - Could not find any changes for "file\314\201withacce\314\200nt.txt" in the ancestry of f1386cd4898696663f83bf62c8f5bc4dc1b463d1
     [java] 2011-06-27 14:45:54,547 WARN  - Inconsistent state while finding the revision for file at path "file\314\201withacce\314\200nt.txt" at changeset f1386cd4898696663f83bf62c8f5bc4dc1b463d1. No revision returned by git.Content hash was: 9daeafb9864cf43055ae93beb0afd6c7d144bfa4
{noformat}
fields.summary: Files with cyrillics in their names generated warning during the indexing of new commits

fields.description:
Feedback from customer 
{quote}
I've never been clear on exactly what goes into the external database. It seems like only Crucible data goes in there, whereas the FishEye cache is all in local disk files. If this is the case, is there any advantage to using an external database in a FishEye-only environment?

Furthermore, if it's true that the external database is only helpful for Crucible users, I would strongly urge you to make that much, much clearer in your documentation and to eliminate the scary bar at the bottom of the admin page admonishing you not to use HSQLDB.

The "robustness" issue vis à vis HSQLDB isn't a big deal for us: in the worst case, we'd just need to wipe out the cache directories and re-index from scratch. Our code base is small enough that this would only be a minor inconvenience. Obviously this would not be true for much larger code bases, but this, too, should be documented as a reason to chose an external database over HSQLDB.

On the other hand, if using an external database improves FishEye performance in some way, I'm more than happy to invest the time and effort into moving over to that.

Regardless of what the answer is, I would again strongly urge you to update the documentation stating exactly what role the external database plays in a FishEye-only setup. Every time I upgrade FishEye I have to think about this situation again, and it would be nice to have a definitive answer about whether I should care about using an external database.{quote}

Clarify use of external database for Fisheye only deployments;
# Repo indexes are stored on disk,
# user data is still stored in hsql DB
# does it have significant performance improvements for medium/small/large deployments
fields.summary: Improve Fisheye documentation for using external databases

fields.description: The JIRA Studio support team has seen this on some instances. According to [~mtaylor@atlassian.com], "It is fairly common for FishEye to chain OOME while indexing files. There is a hardcoded 5mb file limit but it doesn't seem to kick in prior/during svn diffs and instead tries to process the svn diff and dies."
fields.summary: Diffing large files can cause an OutOfMemoryError

fields.description: At least one customer has been confused by our REST docs, which say (e.g.): {{/rest-service/search-v1/reviews?term &maxReturn}}, which leads people to just replace {{term}} with their query, instead of {{term=...}}
fields.summary: REST documentation is confusing

fields.description:
When I view the commit graph for one of my CVS repositories I see what looks like some internal data from a parser when I encounter some special characters. Apostrophe ( ' ) and greater than ( > ) are two characters that generate this output.

ltokxyzdtnhgnsbdfinltok###inltokxyzkdtnhgnsbdfinltok

\#\#\# is some number that increases the further down the page I view.

Other Mercurial and CVS repositories don't exhibit this problem.
fields.summary: Commit graph changeset comments contain ltokxyzdtnhgnsbdfinltok###inltokxyzkdtnhgnsbdfinltok for special characters

fields.description:
In SVN, we just add a tag to the commit which last modified any of the files tagged. This works fine for simple tags and as an indicator for complex tags, but we don't differentiate between them for the user.

Was:

* Need to add the complex field to the tag object
* Add in the determination of complex tags: A root copy source with additional copy/replaces
* Add upgrade task
* Tests
fields.summary: Tags in commit Graph don't indicate whether they are "complex" or not

fields.description:
From Epic FECRU-167: Anchoring #1:

* For SVN and date based versions, if the repo hasn't scanned to that rev/date, Tell the user we may not have seen their version and it may be incorrect (patch warning message)
fields.summary: Patch anchoring: Warning about version/date yet unscanned
